detail_description: The Five Rathas, also known as Pancha Pandava Rathas, are a group of monolithic temples in Mahabalipuram. Each ratha is dedicated to one of the five Pandava brothers from the Hindu epic Mahabharata. Carved out of granite, these temples showcase distinctive architectural styles and intricate details. The individual rathas are named after Draupadi, Arjuna, Bhima, Sahadeva, and Dharmaraja.
name: Five Rathas (Pancha Rathas)
address: 58, W Raja St, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

excerpt: Huge, ancient rock relief with ornate carvings of gods, people & elephants on 2 granite boulders.
detail_description: The Descent of the Ganga River, also known as Arjuna's Penance, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site located in Mahabalipuram, India. This ancient rock relief was commissioned by the Pallava kings and depicts the descent of the sacred river Ganga to earth from the heavens. The relief showcases intricate carvings of gods, people, elephants, and scenes from Hindu mythology and South Indian life.
name: Descent of the Ganga River and Arjuna's Penance
address: J59V+43J, W Raja St, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

excerpt: One of India's oldest structural temples, this Hindu place of worship looks over the Bay of Bengal.
detail_description: The Mahabalipuram Shore Temple is a historic Hindu temple located along the Coromandel coast in India. It is part of a group of sanctuaries that includes rathas, mandapas, and open-air rock reliefs. The temple complex features thousands of sculptures dedicated to Shiva and has been designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The modern city of Mahabalipuram was established nearby in the 19th century by the British Raj.
name: Mahabalipuram Shore Temple
address: Beach Rd, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

excerpt: Collection of approximately 40,000 seashells & marine fossils from around the world.
detail_description: The India Seashell Museum, located near the Pancha Rathas Monument in Mahabalipuram, is a unique and educational attraction showcasing approximately 40,000 seashells and marine fossils from around the world. This newly built museum offers a varied display of snails, oysters, and other shell varieties. It is also home to Asia's largest sea shell collection and features a shopping center called Maya bazaar where visitors can find elegant jewelry and artifacts made from seashells.
name: India Seashell Museum
address: 191/1A2, opposite Five Rathas Street, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

excerpt: Offbeat tourist attraction featuring a massive granite boulder perched on a downhill slope.
detail_description: Krishna's Butter Ball is a unique and offbeat tourist attraction located in Mahabalipuram. It features a massive granite boulder, measuring six meters in height and five meters in width, with an estimated weight of 250 tons. The boulder is perched on a downhill slope in a truly mystical and mysterious manner, defying all laws of physics and reason.
name: Krishna's Butter Ball
address: E Raja St, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

excerpt: Unassuming, sandy beach featuring swimming, surfing & views of the 8th-century Shore Temple.
detail_description: Mahabalipuram Beach, located south of the city of Mahabalipuram, offers a picturesque setting with its white sand and green landscape. Visitors can explore an old ruined Dutch fort and cemetery nearby, showcasing fine stone work and tombstones dating back to the arrival of European powers in India. The beach is famous for its pure white sand and offers opportunities for swimming, surfing, and enjoying views of the 8th-century Shore Temple.
name: Mahabalipuram Beach
address: Tamil Nadu 603104, India

excerpt: Open-air museum featuring an extensive collection of ancient sculptures & replicas of Hindu temples.
detail_description: The Sculpture Museum, located near the Mahabalipuram Bus Station, is a must-visit for those interested in exploring the rich heritage of South India. With over 3000 sculptures and paintings, this open-air museum showcases ancient works of art, predominantly focusing on Hindu mythology characters. The sculptures are made from various materials such as wood, cement, brass, and metal. Visitors can immerse themselves in the historical significance and tales of ancient days depicted by these artworks.
name: Sculpture Museum
address: J58V+8F7, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

excerpt: Mamallapuram, or Mahabalipuram, is a town on a strip of land between the Bay of Bengal and the Great Salt Lake, in the south Indian state of Tamil Nadu. It’s known for its temples and monuments built by the Pallava dynasty in the 7th and 8th centuries. The seafront Shore Temple comprises 3 ornate granite shrines. Krishna’s Butter Ball is a massive boulder balanced on a small hill near the Ganesha Ratha stone temple.
detail_description: Mahabalipuram, also known as Mamallapuram, is a captivating town in Tamil Nadu, India. It's renowned for its ancient temples and monuments constructed by the Pallava dynasty during the 7th and 8th centuries. The Shore Temple, with its three intricate granite shrines, stands proudly along the seafront. Additionally, visitors can marvel at Krishna’s Butter Ball, an enormous boulder delicately balanced on a small hill near the Ganesha Ratha stone temple.
name: Mahabalipuram
address: Tamil Nadu 603104, India

excerpt: Cave temple & UNESCO World Heritage Site with intricate life-sized sculptures, frescoes & columns.
detail_description: The Varaha Cave, located near Mahabalipuram, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a remarkable example of indigenous temple architecture. Constructed in the 7th century in the rock-cut style, it showcases intricate life-sized sculptures, frescoes, and columns. The cave temple is dedicated to Lord Vishnu and features detailed carvings depicting various Hindu gods such as Durga and Gajalakshmi.
name: Varaha Cave
address: J59R+6WM, Madha Kovil St, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

excerpt: Huge, ancient rock relief with ornate carvings of gods, people & elephants on 2 granite boulders.
detail_description: The Descent of the Ganga River, also known as Arjuna's Penance, is a colossal rock-cut relief located in Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu. This ancient site features intricate carvings of gods, people, and elephants on two massive granite boulders. The monument is renowned for its depiction of the legendary story of Arjuna's penance from the Mahabharata and the symbolic event of the descent of the Ganges in Hindu mythology.
name: Descent of the Ganga River / Arjuna's Penance
address: J59V+43J, W Raja St, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

detail_description: The Mahabalipuram Light House, a modern structure built at the end of the 19th century, stands proudly next to the Old Lighthouse. This 85-foot high lighthouse offers panoramic views of the vast seashore and town below. Once known as 'The Land of 7 Pagodas,' this historic site became open to tourists in 2011, allowing visitors to enjoy mesmerizing views from its top.
name: Mahabalipuram Light House
address: Madha Kovil St, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

excerpt: Intricate exterior carvings adorn this Hindu temple cut from pink granite in the 7th century.
detail_description: The Ganesha Ratha is a remarkable Hindu temple carved from pink granite in the 7th century, located within the UNESCO World Heritage site near Mahabalipuram. It is one of ten stone-carved chariots and stands out as a fine example of monolith rock-cut architecture from the Pallava kings' era. Unlike many surrounding rathas, it is a completed structure and was initially home to a Shiva Linga before being dedicated to Lord Ganesha.
name: Ganesha Ratha
address: J59V+92F, Madha Kovil St, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

detail_description: The Trimurti rock-cut cave temple, situated in Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu, is a remarkable example of Pallava architecture dating back to the 7th century. Carved out of a single rock, this shrine features three chambers dedicated to the Hindu trinity - Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva. The intricate carvings and sculptures within the temple showcase the exceptional craftsmanship and artistic skills of the Pallava artisans.
name: Trimurti rockcut cave temple
address: J5CV+36X, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

excerpt: A cave with tiger-head carvings is among the ruins of this 8th-century carved-stone Hindu temple.
detail_description: Tiger Cave, located about 5 km from Mahabalipuram in the Saluvankuppam region, is a picturesque retreat for nature enthusiasts. The site features an 8th-century Hindu temple with tiger-head carvings and a well-maintained lawn surrounded by palm and casuarina trees. It's a popular picnic spot where families can enjoy outdoor activities and even have a photoshoot. Visitors can explore the rock-cut temple and an old Shiva temple on the premises.
name: Tiger Cave
address: Mahabalipuram, Pattipulam, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

excerpt: Compact museum displaying historic lighthouse & maritime equipment, as well as models of ships.
detail_description: Mamallapuram Light House is a historic landmark that offers a glimpse into maritime history and stunning panoramic views. The lighthouse, commissioned in 1884, stands next to the ancient Pallava King Mahendra Pallava's structure dating back to 640 AD. Located on the famous East Coast Road, it provides access to vast beaches. Climbing to the top of the lighthouse provides breathtaking vistas of Mahabalipuram's rock-cut monuments, the Bay of Bengal, and bustling shoreline.
name: Mamallapuram Light House
address: J58R+4PX, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

detail_description: Located in the main Group of Monuments in Mahabalipuram, Pancha Pandava Mandapa is a rock-cut cave temple dedicated to the five Pandava brothers from the epic Mahabharata. Despite being unfinished, it remains a major tourist attraction. The site also features Five Ratha/Chariots dedicated to each Pandava brother and their wife Draupadi, with distinct characteristics for each.
name: Pancha Pandava Cave
address: J59V+32H, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

detail_description: Karukathamman Temple, situated on the East Coast Road between Chennai and Puducherry, is a significant historical site in Mahabalipuram. The temple is dedicated to Goddess Karu Katha Amman, depicted in a sitting position with numerous weapons in her hands and a demon under her feet. The area around the temple offers various attractions such as monuments, museums, resorts, beaches, and other temples like the Shore Temple.
name: Karukathamman Temple
address: 176, Tirukkalukkundram Rd, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

detail_description: Mandapam is a charming coastal town located in the Ramanathapuram district of Tamil Nadu, India. It is known for its pristine beaches, tranquil atmosphere, and stunning views of the Indian Ocean. The town is also famous for its proximity to the Gulf of Mannar Marine National Park, which is home to diverse marine life and coral reefs. Visitors can enjoy activities such as beachcombing, birdwatching, and exploring the nearby fishing villages.
name: Mandapam
address: Mada Koil St, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

excerpt: World Heritage-listed, shoreline, stone temple complex dating from the 7th–8th centuries.
detail_description: The Group of Monuments at Mahabalipuram, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is a collection of ancient stone temples and structures dating back to the 7th–8th centuries. Located on the Coramandel Coast in Tamil Nadu, India, this site features impressive Rathas (chariots), cave sanctuaries, and open-air reliefs such as the famous Arjuna Penance.
name: Group of Monuments at Mahabalipuram
address: Fisherman Colony, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India

detail_description: Draupadi Ratham is a remarkable monolithic rock-cut structure located in Mahabalipuram's Pancha Rathas. This historical site, dating back to around 700 AD and built by the Pallava dynasty, showcases exquisite Indian rock-cut architecture. The Draupadi Ratha is dedicated to Draupadi (Panchali), the common wife of the five Pandava brothers from the epic Mahabharata.
name: Draupadi Ratham
address: J55Q+JV5, Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu 603104, India
